abstract: The Chinese central bank on Wednesday set a key rate for the renminbi at a level that appeared designed to signal that Beijing is engineering only a very gradual appreciation of the Chinese currency against the U.S. dollar.
snippet: The Chinese central bank on Wednesday set a key rate for the renminbi at a level that appeared designed to signal that Beijing is engineering only a very gradual appreciation of the Chinese currency against the U.S. dollar.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese central bank on Wednesday set a key rate for the renminbi at a level that appeared designed to signal that Beijing is engineering only a very gradual appreciation of the Chinese currency against the U.S. dollar, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline.main: Beijing Keeps a Tight Rein on Currency’s Rise

abstract: That whole liberation of the yuan thing sounded good, but it hasn’t amounted to much. Robert Reich has a few astute reasons to think the China “depegging” is baloney.
snippet: That whole liberation of the yuan thing sounded good, but it hasn’t amounted to much. Robert Reich has a few astute reasons to think the China “depegging” is baloney.
lead_paragraph: The idea of liberating the renminbi sounded good, but it hasn’t amounted to much so far.  Robert Reich has a few astute reasons to think the China “depegging” is baloney. A peg that is no peg … you’d have to be Taoist to understand.  Gary Shilling, on the other hand, says Beijing’s move poses some risks.
